At $500 min contribution, they either paid you a ton of money for this( good for you if so) or you did this at a loss( meaning that the effect of the sponsorship is negative and also you ARE endorsing it since that means you did this video for free or worse into the red).
No doing a sponsored video for something you believe in is good. I have no problem with it, you are not selling out or what have you for accepting money for promoting something you believe in.
But... you did state that you believe that better energy generation is the key to the future( paraphrasing), all well and good, I think that it is laudable. But there are many public groups that are doing this kind of research, and while they may be hoping for financial compensation, their aim is for the results to be widely available so to allow this technique to be used in the wider scope of solar panel production. This company, however, is a private concern that seeks to hold private patents on this technology. Meaning that even if they get every dollar they need to not go under, therefore loosing all money invested leaving no results at all, the success of their work will be a held technique that will not be available to other for use(without paying royalties) so your hope/wish/desire for better, broader cheap and clean energy generation is not fulfilled by this, instead the creation of an monopoly.
Don't get me wrong. Private companies can do good, have the money and resources to advance the fields in which the research. And they deserve the rewards for the effort and cost they invest with their own money and time. But if given a choice of giving money from the public to fund research in such fields between a private company that will hold onto any and all discoveries and a public research group that will release the findings and techniques to be used at large and in a wider public manner, then the concern that allows for a broader application that can benefit more ppl and change the industry as a whole and therefore actually impact the manufacturing of solar panels in a more global sense, is the better option.
Sorry for the rant. Long to short - giving my money to a company to develop a technology that they will keep and use for their own, and make themselves more money for the self, over giving my money to a group that will develop the technology to release for use in the whole field at large, I personally believe that the more ppl who can use the technologies equals better for us all.

As a material scientist, here's my take on this

There are 4 main types of photovoltaic materials:
Crystalline silicon;
thin films such as cadmium telluride (CdTe) and copper-indiumgallium-diselenide (CIGS);
and amorphous silicon (a-Si).

The type of photovoltaic material involved in this is crystalline silicon. There's Float Zone Silicon (FZ) and the standard Czochralski Process Silicon (CZ). Float Zone Silicon is more expensive than Si grown from Czochralski Process as it has extremely low concentration of light impurities and nitrogen could be used to improve mechanical strength of Solar panel. And assuming the statistic given is accurate, it could theoretically improve efficiency close to 25%. So yea, it could be more efficient and so for. More research and understanding regarding the subject are important. There are multiple options to explore for the various materials that could be used in solar cells and silicon isn't exactly the most costly part of solar cells, it's just the most costly part of materials involved in the manufacturing process.

Thanks for this excellent video, and all the others. But here you are just describing the well-known Smart-cut technology developped by the company Soitec. It is already a mature technology, I don't see the point of founding it again. Also I don't understant what is amazing about using a particule accelerator to make chips. It's been like since the beginning of micro-electronics in order to dope silicon.
If they really had a process to make it 60% cheaper and 25% more efficient then why would they need to crowd fund? They would drown in venture-capital..

There's a few things I don't understand. On the site they claim to be able to cut down the cost by 60 % . That's impossible if the only way they do it is by reducing silicon use. In fact silicon alone probably doesn't even account for 60% of the cell cost (a lot is due to silver and cell-panel manufacturing). And by the way, maybe they can save half of the silicon because they don't waste it during cutting, but they cannot make the cells too much thinner than they are today, because c-silicon has a low absorption coefficient and needs some depth for all the light to be captured.

Moreover they calim a 25 % efficiency inmprovement , which is misleading since efficiency is already expressed in percentage (basically it would mean going from 20 to 24 %, because going to 45 % is impossible but I don'ìt know if investors understand that), and they don't really explain how that would happen.

I hope they have good ideas and they actually achieve their goals, but if it does it's not because of this technology alone, or it will not be as good as they claim.

I object to the picture at 2:00. In a silicon crystal, the distance between silicon atoms is on the order of 0.5 nm, which is a few orders of magnitude smaller than your 3 um. Remember, we have MOSFETS working with a gate length of 20 nm. There must be several ( in this case 40)
silicon atoms under that gate for that MOSFET to work reliably. Flash memory is a different story, which is the most ubiquitous example of quantum physics.

These kind of process already exist, it is called smartcut process by ionic implantation, it is already used in the industry to make super thin silicon on insulator wafers. I watched most of the video thinking you were telling me that this is a way solar panels are actually made. Later on you imply nobody is doing this yet, but if you give these people money they might be able to. You comment that the thinness of the resulting wafers might justify the cost of using a particle accelerator - is there any evidence to support this, or is it purely optimism on the part of your sponsor?

Being sponsored by an audiobook or web education company is one thing, but when your sponsor gives you a financial incentive to overstate the scientific and other factual claims in your video, run away. You may think the sponsorship won't affect your objectivity (according to psychological research, you are likely to be wrong), but there's no question it affects your viewers' judgement of your objectivity. Short-term cash is nice, but you're better off maintaining a reputation as being someone who is definitely not a shill for industry, let alone possible investment scams.

A cool concept, but EEVblog's video really does highlight the shiftiness of this company and the prospect of investing in it. I've no qualm with sponsored content, but a bit more care taken toward the sort of product sponsored would be appreciated.

Wouldn't the quality of the wafer be affected though? You can calibrate your proton beam to embed proton at, say, 0.003mm depth, but you'd still have many protons embedded at slightly deeper and slightly shallower depths. The depth of the embedded protons would be more or less normally distributed with a mean at 0.003mm depth, so your wafers would certainly have some protons in them...

The Offering

The company is offering up to 32,894,736 shares of Common Stock for $1.52 per share, including up to 1,973,682 shares of Common Stock sold by current securityholders. Sales by current securityholders will not begin until the company has sold at least $7,000,000 worth of its Common Stock. See “Plan of Distribution and Selling Securityholders.” The total number of authorized shares of Common Stock is 200,000,000.

The net proceeds of this offering will be used primarily to develop and validate the company’s technology, to purchase certain assets to advance its plan to produce and market PV modules and for general corporate purposes.

The minimum investment size is $500.

RISK FACTORS

Investing in Rayton Solar’s shares involves risk. In evaluating the company and an investment in the shares, careful consideration should be given to the following risk factors, in addition to the other information included in this Offering Circular. Each of these risk factors could materially adversely affect Rayton Solar’s business, operating results or financial condition, as well as adversely affect the value of an investment in the company’s shares. The following is a summary of the most significant factors that make this offering speculative or substantially risky. The company is still subject to all the same risks that all companies in its industry, and all companies in the economy, are exposed to. These include risks relating to economic downturns, political and economic events and technological developments (such as cyber-security). Additionally, early-stage companies are inherently more risky than more developed companies. You should consider general risks as well as specific risks when deciding whether to invest.

The company has realized significant operating losses to date and expects to incur losses in the future.

The company has operated at a loss since inception, and these losses are likely to continue. Rayton Solar’s net loss for 2015 was $725,762. Until the company achieves profitability, it will have to seek other sources of capital in order to continue operations.

The company’s auditor has issued a “going concern” opinion.

The company’s auditor has issued a “going concern” opinion on its financial statements, which means that the auditor is not sure if the company will be able to succeed as a business without additional financing.

To date, the company has not generated revenues from its principal operations and has sustained losses since inception. Because losses will continue until such time that the company can procure equipment and complete development of its manufacturing technology and because the company has no committed source of financing, the company relies on financing to support its operations. These factors, among others, raise substantial doubt about the ability of the company to continue as a going concern within one year after the date that the financial statements are issued.

Throughout 2016, the company intends to fund its operations through the sale of its securities to third parties and related parties. If the company cannot raise additional capital, it may consume all the cash reserved for operations. There are no assurances that management will be able to raise capital on terms acceptable to the company. If the company is unable to obtain sufficient amounts of additional capital, it may be required to reduce the scope of its planned operations, which could harm the business, financial condition and operating results. The financial statements do not include any adjustments that might result from these uncertainties.

Cool idea in theory, but how much energy does a particle accelerator need to operate? Rayton Solar doesn't provide any data on their website that suggests the operating energy cost of the particle accelerator. You have to consider then the amount of time it would take for the panels to generate the energy used to produce them.

Don't get me wrong, I'm all for clean energy. The great thing about solar panels or any clean energy is that after installation they create no emissions of any sort and after they have generated the amount of energy used to manufacture them they're "producing" net positive energy.

A few more comments on using a particle accelerator:

1) Maintenance - You'll want a technician to be present at all times to monitor the particle accelerator if it malfunctions.
2) Scaling - Particle Accelerators cost a lot of money. If you want to increase production you'll need to buy another particle accelerator.
3) Traditional Manufacturing - Consider a scenario where the particle accelerator breaks or goes down for maintenance. If you only have one particle accelerator, you're shit out of luck and cannot produce your wafers. You would want to have traditional saws or what have you to produce wafers just in case something goes wrong.

I don't claim to know anything about how a particle accelerator works or if maintenance is often needed, but this concept and the company itself just seems like something cool in concept. I'm rooting for solar and all other non-hydrocarbon energy generation methods and would LOVE to be proven wrong, but this is just a fishy company.

Awesome idea! For anyone interested, this is an application of the Bragg curve, which shows that heavy charged particles (of which protons are essentially) deposit most of their energy in a small range. This technology is being applied in radiotherapy in which doctors target tumor cells with these heavy charged particles, essentially by passing the normal cells and destroying only the target area.
